title: Lecture 5
content:
Tuples Examine the code below. What does always_sunny(('cloudy'), ('cold',)) evaluate to?
def always_sunny(t1, t2):""" t1, t2 are non empty """sun = ("sunny","sun")first = t1[0] + t2[0]return (sun[0], first) ('sunny', 'cc') close ('sunny', 'ccold') check ('sunny', 'cloudycold') close Check   Show Solution View video page Download video Download transcript Simple Lists What is the value of L after you run the code below?
L = ["life", "answer", 42, 0]for thing in L:if thing == 0:L[thing] = "universe"elif thing == 42:L[1] = "everything" ["life", "answer", 42, 0] close ["universe", "answer", 42, 0] close ["universe", "everything", 42, 0] check ["life", "everything", 42, 0] close Check   Show Solution View video page Download video Download transcript List Operations What is the value of L3 after you execute all the operations in the code below?
L1 = ['re']L2 = ['mi']L3 = ['do']L4 = L1 + L2L3.extend(L4)L3.sort()del(L3[0])L3.append(['fa','la']) ['mi', 're', ['fa', 'la']] check ['mi', 're', 'fa', 'la'] close ['re', 'mi', ['fa', 'la']] close ['do', 'mi', ['fa', 'la']] close Check   Show Solution View video page Download video Download transcript List Aliasing/Mutation What is the value of brunch after you execute all the operations in the code below?
L1 = ["bacon", "eggs"]L2 = ["toast", "jam"]brunch = L1L1.append("juice")brunch.extend(L2) ['bacon', 'eggs', 'toast', 'jam'] close ['bacon', 'eggs', 'juice', 'toast', 'jam'] check ['bacon', 'eggs', 'juice', ['toast', 'jam']] close ['bacon', 'eggs', ['toast', 'jam']] close Check   Show Solution View video page Download video Download transcript
